DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAW REFORM COMMISSION BILL 1996Cognate bill:AUSTRALIAN LAW REFORM COMMISSION (REPEAL, TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports wholeheartedly the Australia Law Reform Commission Bill and the Australia Law Reform Commission (Repeal, Transitional and Miscellaneous) Bill. It is particularly pleasing for me to support these bills because, in the last parliament, I was the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which inquired into the Law Reform Commission of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The current Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams) was also a member of that committee. It was obvious throughout the hearings that the Law Reform Commission had cross‐party support. We undertook the first comprehensive review of the commission in its 20‐year existence. It is really pleasing to note that our review showed that the Law Reform Commission was a dynamic organisation that was producing quality reports and was giving quality independent advice to government. It is essential in a democracy like ours that we have something like the Law Reform Commission.

The previous government had picked up, as I understand it, most of the recommendations of my parliamentary committee. This current government has also done that. I think that is testimony to the cross‐party support that the Law Reform Commission rightfully enjoys. The one sad aspect is that budget cuts will affect the operation of the Law Reform Commission because, in the document Meeting our commitments, the coalition admitted that cuts would affect the commission. They will result in a small reduction in the number of reports produced by the commission.

The commission's budget of $3.9 million per year will be cut by $0.5 million per year, or 12.8 per cent. That was announced during the election campaign and was administered in the budget yesterday. That is a small hiccup and I am sure that a dynamic organisation such as the Law Reform Commission will be able to make the necessary adjustments. What worries me in the current climate is that it is going to be very hard for some people to say, `No, this is not the way to go.' That is why we need an independent Law Reform Commission.

I notice that the Attorney‐General, in his usual courteous fashion, is here today, paying us the courtesy of listening to this debate. I appreciate that. I have said it a number of times—and I cannot say it enough—that, while I do not agree with everything that the Attorney‐General is doing because obviously we do differ on a number of things—and I respect and understand that—I must say that he brings distinction to his position.

BREAK.PARA: The position of Attorney‐General is one that, in a cabinet, needs to be a challenging position and one that is understood to be so. The Attorney‐General cannot be a yes‐man or a yes‐woman. He or she is the first law officer of the Crown, who needs to take on the cabinet at times—and the cabinet needs to understand that. The Attorney‐General is there to provide proper advice in relation to the existing law.

The Attorney‐General has really the same role and function as the Australian Law Reform Commission, which is there to keep us all honest and not to pander to prejudice in the community or to the lowest common denominator, nor to advise politically or in a partisan fashion. It is there to assist us as law‐makers and to provide the Attorney‐General with independent and proper advice. It is not there to have all its recommendations picked up, but it is part of the equation. It is part of the jigsaw, as is the Attorney‐General's office. The Attorney‐General made an outstanding contribution in the last parliament to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It is interesting that, on each occasion that he has had the opportunity in government, he has attempted to build on the recommendations and the views that he expressed when he was on the backbench.

The downside is that we should not get carried away with all this backslapping and bipartisanship, because we need to continually be on our mettle. I am fearful that, in the current climate of the push for law and order, tougher sentencing and a whole range of so‐called reforms in the legal and justice area, we are being driven by the lowest common denominator, the redneck radio commentators, the ill‐informed and the prejudiced.

In 10 years as a practising solicitor and barrister in New South Wales, I never had a case accurately or properly reported by the press. It was always sensationally reported. The Law Reform Commission and advisory bodies like that bring us, as politicians, back to heel a little. What we need are considered, informed debates and an independent, vibrant, Law Reform Commission to give us non‐partisan, non‐political advice. What we are about is good law.

Looking at the American way of doing things, I do not think that is the path to go down. That is why I wholeheartedly support what the Attorney‐General has done, and so does the opposition as a whole. We are pleased to give our support to this bill. It is a bill about which we can say, `We laid the foundations for it, and the ball has been passed to this government and, in effect, they are running over and scoring the try.' That is the case. It has been basically a partnership in the implementation of this bill.

It was not that way when we started our inquiry into the Law Reform Commission. It is fair to say that there was a view around that we could probably do without the Law Reform Commission and that it, in some areas, had not been up to scratch. There is no doubt that the dynamism of the people who have headed the Law Reform Commission has impacted on the sorts of reports that the commission has done, and that it has evolved. There is no doubt that occasionally its emphasis has not necessarily been endorsed.

It was interesting throughout our inquiry that there were a number of professionals within the legal profession and a number of people within the business community who were prepared to donate their time to assist in the compilation of reports and to provide professionalism to the reports that the Law Reform Commission was providing for this parliament and the nation. They were able to do that because of their sense of professionalism, and the high regard in which the Law Reform Commission is held. A parliamentary committee cannot do that.

I know there was a view around that maybe we could do away with the Law Reform Commission and set up a parliamentary committee that has those particular functions. I do not agree with that. The less the politicians are involved in areas like this, the better, because what we do, in a number of instances, is that whilst we are well‐meaning we do not have that experience, that professionalism, on the ground. We have changed; we may well have thought we were good lawyers before we entered parliament, but the truth is that you do lose that contact on the ground. That is something that the Law Reform Commission can do—as an independent, statutory body it can reach into a whole range of professional communities and produce quality reports.

The title of our report to the parliament was Law reform: the challenge continues and I think the Law Reform Commission is taking up the challenge, especially in the current climate. This is particularly so because, as a centralist—and I do not apologise for that—I think it is absurd in a nation such as ours, as we are heading to the centenary of Federation, that we have six state jurisdictions and two territory jurisdictions so that, but for an accident of birth or depending on where you are in Australia, you are subject to different penalties and different rules apply. That is why with the Law Reform Commission, arising out of the reports and arising out of this bill, there is some flexibility. What we are looking for is a national approach to coordinate the states so that there is no division.

If you are a Queenslander, why should you be dealt with differently by the law than if you were born in New South Wales and dealt with in New South Wales? This is where the Law Reform Commission assists us because it is able to overarch, to reach into those state instrumentalities, to find agreement—and it is not easy—and bring down a proper perspective. So I commend the bill to the parliament. It has the wholehearted support of the opposition. Indeed, it is fair to say that our fingerprints are all over it—and proudly so. But so are the Attorney‐General's.

It is important to acknowledge that, in terms of the reference that the last parliament dealt with, it was the current Attorney‐General who was the driving force behind the reference and was enthusiastic about our doing the reference. I know he is a supporter of the Law Reform Commission—as he should be because, on any proper analysis of what it has done over the last 20 years, it really does get the big tick. And what it again shows is that, in the Law Reform Commission, a lot of the people involved are committed to public service in the true professional sense.

It also shows that there are those in the private professions who are prepared to work with the Law Reform Commission and who, instead of charging the thousands and thousands of dollars they quite rightly can command in their own professions, donate many of their services for free, from a sense of public duty. We found that it was just token travel expenses that were being met. That is the benefit of the Law Reform Commission. It is part of the equation. It is part of that partnership that the parliament has with the community. So I commend the Attorney for picking up most of the recommendations in our report and carrying them through in the current climate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say it is somewhat humbling to follow the member for Banks (Mr Melham) who was chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when the report which is the basis of this legislation was handed down. I also note that the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), who is in the chamber today and was a member of the committee at the same time, indicated in his second reading speech that he was pleased to be able to implement, in his role as Attorney‐General, substantially the bulk of the recommendations of the committee which were contained in the report titled Law reform: the challenge continues .

SPEECH.PARA: The former Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, indicated that the overriding principles, as he saw the government's role in terms of the legal system, were threefold. Firstly, all Australians should have equality before the law. Secondly, Australians, regardless of their place of residence, should have similar rights and privileges. Thirdly, Australians should have equal access to legal services.

Clearly, if obtaining justice is prohibitive for ordinary Australians, the legal system becomes all but irrelevant to them. If our legal system does not remain both relevant and accessible, it will have repercussions for our legal system itself and, of course, for the principle of the rule of law, which we all cherish so dearly.

It is in that context that the role of the Law Reform Commission can be particularly worthwhile. It is my experience that the cost of access to the law is not only a result of the costs of the participants, the lawyers, the transcript fees and the filing fees, but also results in large part from legal complexities which can necessitate litigants requiring the services of those specialist lawyers. So any steps that can be taken to make the law more relevant and accessible and to simplify it will ultimately be of benefit to our legal system.

I note that the thrust of these bills is not only to give the Australian Law Reform Commission a new title and to update and modernise the drafting of the former provisions, but also to affect three other significant areas. The legislation will require the Law Reform Commission, as it will be reconstituted, to consider proposals for complementary laws between the Commonwealth, the states and the territories; to have regard to such of Australia's international treaty obligations as are relevant; and to take into account the implications of its recommendations on lowering the cost of justice. It is those three issues which I would like to address today.

I would like to speak firstly in terms of complementary laws, perhaps not only because it is topical but also because it is very relevant as part of the make‐up of our society today, about the efficient functioning of our industrial relations system. If I can give one example of the complexities that exist, it is in respect of the provision which is proposed in the Workplace Relations Bill for the disamalgamation of trade unions.

We exist, under the federal system, in a position where trade unions are usually registered under that federal system and also under state systems. Quite frequently, the trade unions which are registered under the state systems are, in effect, the same as the branches of the federal body. It is usually the case that the membership is duplicated. Yet, under those separate state systems, it is frequently the case that the legislation purports to give a separate corporate identity to that state union.

The government is faced with a position and, indeed, the trade unions are faced with a position of trying to identify, literally, who is who in the zoo. With respect to the disamalgamation of trade unions, it will not only be a question of unscrambling the egg in terms of the division of assets and the division of members but also there will be the question of identifying which chicken the egg came from and then allocating the chicken to the appropriate jurisdiction, whether it be state or federal and whether that can be done at all.

If the amalgamation was the result of, say, a federation of those state registered trade unions, it may be that the federal legislation cannot have any impact on them at all. I do not wish to discuss the federal industrial relations legislation. I am merely pointing out that great complications arise every day as a result of our federal system and hence the need to reform. It creates complexities in trade unions and it creates complexities for any enforcement agency trying to work out who is responsible for a particular conduct, or against which body some particular award or penalty could be enforced. Similarly, the same thing would apply to employer organisations which wanted to seek some redress. The inconvenience and dislocation apply across the board.

I am not suggesting that the government has created that dislocation or uncertainty. The problems were first demonstrated in 1972 and it resulted in the Sweeney inquiry, as it was then known. But, regrettably, the federal and state legislatures have seen fit to do very little about it in that 24‐year period. Hopefully, with this new and specific direction, the Law Reform Commission can roll up its sleeves and look at issues that permeate our everyday lives.

The second area that the Law Reform Commission has an obligation to consider is Australia's international treaty obligations, as they are relevant to Australia. This is an increasingly important area. The significance of treaties has been underlined by the fact that the federal parliament has, as I recall, with bipartisan support, established the treaties committee—it is now the second largest joint standing committee—to look at international treaties before they are made and to review treaties that are already in force.

In more recent times, the High Court has referred to Australia's international treaty obligations in considering the development of the common law which, fortunately, continues to live, grow, adapt and mould itself according to society as we know it. We have now come to a situation where the High Court recognises that Australia is part of an international community and that what happens in that international community will affect the very fabric of our own society and the infrastructure of laws itself. That is, in my opinion, a highly desirable eventuality and trend. It is one which I believe will continue, largely irrespective of which government is in power.

Australia is a middle order power on the world stage, and we have two choices: we can participate in an international community where there is a developing and growing international rule of law, or we can return to the days of the 1950s, 1960s and into the 1970s, where we were substantially beholden to the respective calls made by the superpowers. It is in our interests, I would submit, that the influence of the five or six superpowers, as they are known, be tempered by a mutuality, established between all nations and existing and developing the international rule of law to which I have referred; and Australia can play a part in the development of such mutuality through negotiating, developing and reviewing treaties. This is an appropriate role, as I have indicated, in which the Law Reform Commission could look at not only what has happened domestically but also what has occurred through our attaching and linking ourselves to the international community and, indeed, to the international standards as set by international treaty documents.

The third and final area which is highly significant is the obligation cast upon the Australian Law Reform Commission to have regard to the costs of justice. As I have earlier noted, the cost of justice is itself significant, in terms of the access that the ordinary Australian can have to the legal system—and not only the ordinary Australian but also the business community. I must say that, in my former employment as a solicitor, I was involved in one or two pieces of litigation on a personal basis; and, even though I had the resources of a legal firm supporting me, I spent a few hours awake during the night worrying about the possible consequences of the legal costs and, indeed, the all but disaster which would befall if the litigation were lost. I can well imagine how much more accentuated those costs would be for an ordinary Australian who did not have such resources. When we have come to that situation in life, we clearly have to take stock and have a look at the lie of the land.

In that context, I note some concern that there is a trend to recoup, if you like, the cost of justice by the court registries themselves. That is something which applies in the states, and I note that there is presently a draft bill—which I will not discuss, because it is quite inappropriate here—to raise the filing fees of federal tribunals. I would ask all those involved, however, to recognise that there are not only up‐front costs of litigation, in the sense of paying for lawyers, which is but one aspect of the legal costs, but also the costs of filing fees—which, in some instances in the Federal Court, may well increase to $1,600—to be added to the cost of transcripts, for instance, which currently would cost a litigant approximately $750 per day, in addition to what they are paying for the barristers and for the solicitors. Even where there is supposedly a cost free jurisdiction currently, such as under the Industrial Relations Act 1988, those hidden costs still apply. Each litigant still has to meet the costs of that $750 per day transcript.

All these hidden costs have to be factored into any equation when we are considering access to justice. Again it is entirely appropriate that the Law Reform Commission looks at those matters and other matters it may have regard to in terms of the cost of litigation.

Another significant area on which I would hope the Law Reform Commission would focus in its independent role is access to legal resource materials. In this parliament we are very fortunate indeed in the access we have through our computer network system to a wide range of resources through the Parliamentary Library, including access to High Court cases, state cases, legislation and the like. It has to be a fact that, if that resource base becomes more accessible throughout the community, the reduced cost of finding the law or researching the law will bring down the costs of law. So I hope that is one area to which the Law Reform Commission will consider it appropriate to give further consideration.

There is one negative aspect. While I give due recognition to the support of the Attorney‐General for the Law Reform Commission which was commented on by the member for Banks in his speech before mine, I am concerned that, in the context of the complexities and the developments to which I have referred, the government has seen fit to reduce the funding available to the Law Reform Commission. That is something which I regret and, indeed, the Labor opposition regrets. We hope that, as this newly constituted—if you like—Law Reform Commission undertakes its task, the government may well reconsider the question of funding that body. I think it will be found that with its new charter the Law Reform Commission will become even more effective and deserving of support. I support the bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —To address the last comment made by the previous speaker, the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), no‐one disputes the value of the Law Reform Commission. However, this government, as everyone knows, inherited from the former Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) a budget black hole of $10.3 billion. Regrettably, the Law Reform Commission, along with all other groups in the Australian community, must accept some pain for the ultimate gain that will benefit all of us. I know that those opposite would agree that the budget last night was a very good budget, a very fair budget, a very equitable budget, a budget that will deliver a very good future for Australia.
—Short on fairness, full on prejudice: opinion poll—

—I am very pleased to see the honourable member for Banks present. Indeed, he was the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which produced the report entitled Law reform: the challenge continues , and the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), at the table here, was a member of that committee, as was I. I must compliment the honourable member for Banks on the fact that he did a wonderful job as chairman of that committee, particularly in relation to that report. I suggest to the Attorney that the honourable member for Banks may well have done a better job as chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs than he will as the opposition spokesman on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. What indeed he should be doing in that capacity is backing the very positive initiatives announced by Senator Herron, the minister, which will assist Aboriginal health and education and attack the problem of infant mortality.
—Come on! Fair go!
—Order! The member for Fisher might return to the bill before the Main Committee and not further provoke the member for Banks.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your guidance. This particular bill largely implements the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and is yet another indication of the success of the House of Representatives committee system. The future of the Law Reform Commission was referred to this committee after the Law Reform Commission had been in existence for some 20 years. This is largely a housekeeping bill. After the Law Reform Commission has played a role for 20 years it is sensible to review the legislation; it is appropriate to review the functions of the Law Reform Commission. In effect, it is important to take a stocktake to ensure that the Australian taxpayer is receiving value for dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: We had, I think, some 61 submissions, and we made 40 recommendations. The new Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), having succeeded his Labor predecessor, has considered the recommendations of the committee and has brought forward this bill. The Attorney‐General, I believe, is very well qualified to consider matters in the area of law reform, having been the chairman of the Law Reform Commission of Western Australia when he was in private practice in that state.

The bill does a number of things. It formally changes the name of the commission to the Australian Law Reform Commission. It requires the commission to consider proposals for complementary laws between the Commonwealth and the states and territories, to have regard for such of Australia's international treaty obligations as are relevant, and to take into account the implications of its recommendations on lowering the cost of justice.

The bill also enables the commission to appoint consultants, it clarifies the role of the deputy president and provides for the appointment of an acting president in the president's absence or when the office of president is vacant. It also provides for the establishment of a board of management comprising the president, deputy president and full‐time members. It confers chief executive officer powers on the president or the president's delegate and confers appropriate powers on the full commission or a delegate of the full commission.

Most importantly, the bill also provides members and staff with immunity from civil action, the cause of which necessarily or reasonably arises in the course of duties being honestly undertaken before the commission. In these days of financial stringency, no doubt it is a very great relief to see that there will be no additional financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by these bills.

I found the evidence before the committee to be very thought provoking. The committee was able to attract a large number of submissions from a very broad range of people involved in the law reform community throughout Australia. One of the things the committee did was to review the situation in individual states and it was quite interesting to see that the law reform process is approached quite differently in different parts of Australia.

I agreed substantially with the results of the deliberations of the committee; however, in the report I registered an expression of concern in relation to a number of areas. I did not elevate the expression of concern, to the chairman's relief, to that of a dissenting report, but I was concerned particularly about three issues. I was convinced by the arguments of the Premier of Western Australia that the Law Reform Commission ought to, in fact, be referred to as the Commonwealth Law Reform Commission because that would indicate a clear demarcation of the work undertaken by the commission. I took the view, and mentioned in the report, that the designation `Commonwealth Law Reform Commission' would be a more appropriate manner in which to describe the Commonwealth body responsible for federal law reform.

Some people would say that the Australian Law Reform Commission has a facilitating role in relation to law reform beyond the area of Commonwealth responsibility and that it has liaised quite successfully with state bodies and, I believe, bodies across the Tasman with a view to attaining, to the greatest degree possible, uniformity of law. It is obvious that the new government has accepted the recommendation of the committee that the name be changed from the Law Reform Commission of Australia to the Australian Law Reform Commission.

I had, however, a more major concern in relation to the preparation of draft legislation accompanying the reports of the Law Reform Commission. The former chairman, who is sitting opposite, would well remember my views on this matter. I recall that, on many occasions, the Law Reform Commission would bring down reports which would be sent to the Attorney and government of the day for consideration. The government would take a considerable amount of time to decide what its response was going to be.

Rarely would the government agree to implement the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in full. The draft legislation, which was prepared by the Law Reform Commission, would often languish and be unused. Even if the government accepted partially the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission, by the time it came forward with a response the draft legislation, prepared at great cost to the Australian taxpayer, was entirely out of date. In fact, there was some evidence before the committee that the preparation of draft legislation was a delaying factor in the production of reports of the Law Reform Commission. I remain very concerned about this matter.

It is important for the government to consider reports of the Law Reform Commission as expeditiously as possible. I have no doubt that the current Attorney will not permit the delays which have existed in the past to continue. I just do not really see the point in preparing draft legislation when there is no certainty at all that there will be a change in law. I personally feel that the time to prepare the draft legislation is when the government says what it wants the new law to be. However, I am in a minority on that issue and I presume that the Law Reform Commission will, when it deems it appropriate, continue to prepare draft legislation to accompany reports passed on to the government for consideration.

BREAK.PARA: The question of international treaty obligations is a matter that has concerned me for a very long time. I outlined in the report the hypocrisy of the Labor government. One thing that did concern me greatly was the way that this country could sign and ratify a treaty by the Governor‐General sitting in Executive Council with any two ministers. It could be binding on Australia even though the particular subject matter of that treaty had not been referred even to the cabinet, the ministry, the government party, either house of the parliament or the Australian people.

I know that the coalition has a more effective treaty making process. It has more appropriate procedures and these will progressively be put in place but, nevertheless, one of the problems that we have as a nation is that we have entered into some 2,000 treaties concerning a broad range of areas. No‐one would object to some of those treaties but there are others where from time to time the collective values of the Australian community may change. If there is no provision for withdrawal from a treaty, either set out in the terms of the treaty or able to be implied from the terms of the treaty, then my understanding is that the only way that this country can withdraw from such a treaty is to go back and renegotiate with all of the other contracting parties to that treaty. Sometimes more than 100 countries sign a treaty and, therefore, there could be some treaties from which this country could never escape, should the values of the country no longer be represented by that treaty.

International law is becoming increasingly important. Many people in my electorate would say, `Well, what we should do is simply tear a treaty up if we don't agree with the terms of it'. But, of course, that could put Australia out of step with its international obligations and we would not want Australia to be an international outlaw.

As I said, I largely support the report of the committee. The government, naturally, supports this bill because it is a government bill. I am pleased that the opposition is joining with us in endorsing this particular piece of legislation. It will give, after some 23 years, an even more efficient Law Reform Commission to serve the people of Australia very well into the next century. I commend the bill to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The government is very grateful to the opposition for its support of this bill, and I also would like to thank the member for Banks (Mr Melham), the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mention has been made by all speakers of the work of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the previous parliament. I think that committee will stand as a model for the development of legislation in the national interest. I would like to think that there will be in this parliament and in future parliaments committees that will operate on that basis.

I believe its success was attributable to a number of things; its membership among others. The chairman, the member for Banks, was instrumental in its achievements because of his willingness to commit the committee to examination of issues on their merits. Most of the material that came before the committee was dealt with on a bipartisan basis and the selection of references has something to do with its success. But at the same time, under the chairmanship of the member for Banks, the issues were fairly and squarely addressed, and I congratulate him on his record in that respect. Other members of the committee made a significant contribution. The member for Fisher was a conscientious member, as were the former member for Holt and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), among others. I think the work of the House standing committees is important. It has been under‐utilised and underestimated as a resource, but I think the selection of references is an important part of the success.

In relation to the reference to that committee on the Australian Law Reform Commission as it is to become, that was a very thorough piece of work, reviewing a body which has functioned for many years and attained significant successes itself. The report is, in basic terms, a set of recommendations on the structure and operation, as well as the functions, of the commission. I think it will set a new direction for the commission in its operation.

The member for Banks suggested that the fingerprints of the previous government were all over it. I do not really agree with that. I think the fingerprints of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs are all over the report. While he suggested that the present government was going to score the try, I would see it as being a triumph for that previous committee.

The member for Barton made some comments on a number of matters referred to in the report and in the bill. In particular, he referred to the proposals for implementing complementary state and territory laws, the proposal that in performing its functions the commission have regard to relevant treaty obligations and finally the obligations of the commission to have regard to the costs of access to justice. In the latter respect he particularly referred to court and tribunal fees proposed in yesterday's budget. I will not say anything about that; I will save comments for the appropriate time and the appropriate forum.

He also mentioned the reduced budget. In that respect, let me say the budget reductions to the ALRC were a component of clearly signalled policy in pursuance of the government's program of savings measures and were set out in its election document Meeting our Commitments. It is true that the savings will to some extent reduce the commission's capacity to undertake several major references at once but I have been assured by the commission that it will be able to progress all its current references as planned and it will be able to undertake a further major new reference commencing in the current financial year. It will still be possible to give the commission additional work. In particular, the commission will be able to take on additional references on issues where funding is provided, in effect, by a client department specifically on a direct reference basis. The savings will to some extent reduce the commission's extracurricular activities but the resultant strategic planning will mean that the commission will be more focused on its primary task of reporting and advising the government on priority areas of law reform.

The member for Fisher mentioned his expressions of concern, which are in the report of the House Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Commonwealth Law Reform Commission suggestion was not picked up by the other members of the committee. In fact, the recommendation that the committee be called the ALRC is merely a reflection of common parlance. It has for many years been referred to as the Australian Law Reform Commission or the ALRC, despite the statute naming it the Law Reform Commission.

The subject of draft legislation was debated at length within the committee. The views of the member for Fisher are well known on the subject. My personal view expressed repeatedly in those debates was that, in many instances, a commission would use the mechanism of drafting legislation as a means of identifying issues for consideration in the course of a reference, whether the draft legislation was sought by the actual reference, and whether that draft legislation was appended to the report.

PARA.TAB: Finally, in relation to treaties, I think that the member for Fisher can rest easy because the coalition's policy has been effectively implemented. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Downer) and I on 2 May, the second sitting day of this government, introduced a number of measures and, subsequent to that, we have had the formation of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. COAG, at its meeting in June, established a Treaties Council, involving the state and territory governments. The commission will, under the bill, in performing its functions have regard to all relevant treaty obligations.

BREAK.PARA: In closing the debate, I submit that the proposed legislation is a demonstration of the government's commitment to having a viable law reform agency which is able to advise it on keeping Australia's laws up to date. The government agrees with the committee chaired by the member for Banks in its recognition of the importance of having a permanent and separate agency to provide detailed policy advice on law reform matters to the Attorney‐General and the parliament.
I commend the bill to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 June, on motion by Mr Williams:

DEBATE.TITLE: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN CRIMINAL MATTERS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we have a situation where the opposition supports the bill before this committee and the House. I think that it needs to be acknowledged that the reason that this is happening often in the early part of this session—and I will give the background to this—is that one needs to acknowledge that the current government has picked up virtually all of the previous government's bills. We need to acknowledge the tremendous work that was put in by the previous Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch, and the previous Minister for Justice and the current member for Denison (Mr Kerr) in relation to a number of bills that we have debated in this session of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a testimony to the work that they have put in that most of those bills have been picked up by the present government and have been championed in the same form as in when they were introduced into the previous parliament. That shows that in a lot of areas there is cross‐ party support for these proposals. That is not to say that there has not been vigorous debate behind the scenes or differences of opinion on either side of the House.

However, I acknowledge the tremendous commitment to law reform of the previous Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch, and the current member for Denison. It is true that in the last parliament—and, again, it needs to be acknowledged—many of the reforms were reforms championed by another previous Attorney‐General, my good friend the Hon. Michael Duffy. The contribution that he made when he was Attorney‐General was not acknowledged enough, unfortunately. That contribution carried on after he left that office because many of the reforms that others picked up and ran with were reforms that he initiated.

This bill follows an exhaustive review of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act, held in consultation with the private profession, representative civil liberties groups and interested government agencies. The terms of approval by the new government are almost identical, except for minor technical differences, to the terms of approval of the previous Labor government.

In August 1994, the former Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch, approved the circulation of an issues paper to all federal, state and territory prosecution and investigation agencies, law societies, bar associations, the Law Council of Australia and representative civil liberties associations. All but two recommendations in the issues paper were accepted by all respondents.

In mid‐1995, the previous Labor government approved the introduction of legislation to implement the recommendations in the review paper, plus a number of additional technical matters and two additions specifically requested by the previous Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch. This needs to be acknowledged. There was the specific death penalty refusal ground which is in the act. It is currently clause 41, and I will come to that shortly. That provision, I might add, was also supported by the member for Denison, the previous Minister for Justice, and that has been picked up by this government. So what my good friend the Hon. Michael Duffy used to call `the hangers and the floggers' have not had their way in relation to this act.

The other provision was to enable a defendant to apply to a foreign country for assistance. That was something that the previous Attorney‐General championed. It has been picked up in this bill because that legislation was not introduced before the election. But this bill, certainly as introduced, implements the policy agreed by cabinet in May 1995, as I say, including the clause in relation to the death penalty and the one on access to defendants.

In particular, I want to talk about item 41, subclauses 8(1A) and 8(1B). Basically, it is worthwhile reading on to the record what is in the explanatory memorandum, because I think that sets it all out. It states:
59. This item inserts 2 new subclauses after subsection 8(1) relating to refusal of assistance in relation to offences carrying the death penalty in the requesting country.

60. Subclause 8(1A) provides that the Attorney‐General must refuse a request for assistance from a foreign country if it relates to the prosecution or punishment of a person charged with or convicted of an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed; the subsection allows the Attorney‐General limited discretion to grant the assistance sought if there are special circumstances in the particular case. Such circumstances would arise if the evidence sought could be exculpatory. Normally assistance would not be granted unless the requesting state gave an assurance that the death penalty, if imposed, would not be carried out. However it would not be appropriate for Australia to insist that an assurance be given in all cases. For example it would not be appropriate for an assurance to be required where the assistance sought by the request is of an exculpatory nature.

61. Item 41 also inserts new subclause 8(1B) which provides that, if the Attorney‐General believes provision of the assistance may result in the death penalty being imposed on a person, the Attorney‐General may refuse the assistance, after taking into account the interests of international criminal co‐operation, if the Attorney‐General is of the opinion that in the circumstances of the case assistance should be refused.

62. Subclause 8(1A) will apply where charges carrying the death penalty have been laid in a foreign country (or the person has been convicted of an offence carrying the death penalty); in these circumstances assistance must be refused except in special circumstances. Subclause 8(1B) applies where charges have not yet been laid in the foreign country. In such requests it is intended that there be more discretion available to the Attorney‐General to grant assistance. In the exercise of the discretion the Attorney‐General may take into account the interests of international criminal co‐operation (including the desire to maximise possibilities of reciprocal assistance by the foreign country to Australia and of the general international interest in cross‐jurisdictional assistance in serious criminal matters) and the surrounding circumstances of the case.
That is what is in the explanatory memorandum. It adequately encompasses a description of what that section is about.

It is certainly something that I endorse. It is Labor policy and it has been introduced in this bill. The Labor Party supports its inclusion. I, in particular, support its inclusion. I do not describe myself as part of the `hangers and floggers'. I think it is right and appropriate that this bill contains these clauses. I commend this government for putting that clause in. It is one of the reasons that the legislation has cross‐party support.

I am not one who believes in the death penalty; I say that here and now. There are many instances where it has been shown that, if the death penalty had been carried out, many innocent people whose convictions were subsequently quashed would not have been around to see that. You only have to look at the `Birmingham four' and the `Guildford six'. You only have to look at the number of commissions around Australia today, and the reports to the parliament, to see the level of corruption that exists and has now tainted some—not all—convictions. I am not a proponent of the death penalty—of state‐induced death—and I commend the government for putting that clause in.

I think it is proper and appropriate to acknowledge that it was the previous Attorney‐General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch, and the previous Minister for Justice who championed this clause going into the drafting instructions. It certainly enriches the legislation. It is the way it should be, and there should be no apologies.

That is not to say that there is not the odd critic or the odd person who does not believe in that clause. We are never going to have unanimous agreement. But I think it has been a considered discussion paper and it has been considered legislation. That is the way legislation in this area should be dealt with: it should be open to scrutiny. We, as a parliament, should be inviting public scrutiny.

We should be achieving cross‐party support where possible. These issues are above politics. These issues are important, and it is important that they be dealt with in a cross‐party manner. I commend the government, in this regard, for bringing this legislation in, and I do not apologise for that. Too often there is a misconception in the community that we are always fighting with one another and scoring cheap political points. The reverse is true. The tragedy is that the modern‐day reporting of parliament—indeed, the only reporting that the media are interested in doing—consists of the clashes that we have, because it is popular television stuff. They are only interested in confrontation and not in consultation or conciliation. They are not interested in showing pictures of peaceful demonstrators, or whatever. The only good television, for them, is where an incident takes place, and that is not the way to deal with sensitive legislation such as this.

That is why we, as an opposition, are consistently getting up and supporting these pieces of legislation. It shows that, in this area, there has been cross‐party support, and that the legislation which we introduced was not bad legislation, because it has been picked up by the current government. They deserve the credit for that, and we will give credit where it is due. With those remarks, I commend the legislation to the committee and to the House. The opposition will assist in giving it speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today in support of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. The principal act came into force on 1 August 1988 and has been described as one of the most far‐reaching statutes on criminal law and criminal procedure ever enacted by an Australian legislature. It provides the statutory basis for Australia to enter into arrangements with other countries when requesting information or the prosecution of cross‐border crime and the recovery of assets, including moneys, obtained as a result of that crime.

SPEECH.PARA: A review of the Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements of February 1994 reported that the nature of major and organised crime had changed. Known criminal organisations and networks in Australia and other countries have increased in size and power. The technology they use is more difficult to log and monitor. Many criminal organisations have developed interests beyond their countries of origin. Organisations and networks based in other countries are now represented in Australia or have links with Australian‐based networks.

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act, in particular, has provided invaluable assistance to the Australian law enforcement authorities—including the federal and state police forces, the National Crime Authority and the Australian Customs Service—in the conduct of transnational criminal cases, particularly on crimes such as drug trafficking. The key to the amendments to the act provided for in this bill is the improvements which have come about as a result of consultation with law enforcement, legal and civil liberties organisations. I speak in particular of the measure that the member for Banks (Mr Melham) referred to at length. This is the critical measure which includes the provision that the Attorney‐General must refuse assistance from a foreign country if it relates to the prosecution or punishment of a person charged with, or convicted of, an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed.

This provision is extremely important because in practice, before, we were allowed avenues of refusal in respect of these circumstances if the matter was non‐specific to the death penalty. This provision will reflect Australia's policy, given that the death penalty has been abolished since 1984 in all Australian states and that we are party to the second optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This amendment does, however, allow the Attorney‐General discretion to grant assistance sought, if there are special circumstances in the particular case: for example, where the assistance sought is exculpatory in nature and establishes the innocence of, or else exonerates, the defendant.

Another key amendment allows for a residual non‐specific refusal ground where, in the opinion of the Attorney‐General, it is appropriate in all the circumstances of the case that the request for assistance should not be granted. Previously, assistance could only be granted to countries to which the act applied by regulation, and regulations would only be made where Australia had faith in the criminal justice system of that particular country.

Previously, a request for cooperation from a country not mentioned in our regulations could encounter a delay of at least eight weeks while regulations were made by the Federal Executive Council. Such a delay could considerably undermine the effectiveness of the act for investigative and prosecution agencies. Assistance can now be provided and requested much more expeditiously.

Amendments also deal with court applications by the defendant, restrictions on the use of information received, court‐to‐court applications to take evidence and other amendments mostly of a technical or mechanical nature. All will improve the operation of the act which has proved absolutely necessary for Australia to counter transnational crime, including drug trafficking and other forms of organised crime, and will also show us, in the international arena, as jealous of civil and political rights, which we hold most dear in this country. I therefore commend the bill to this committee and ask that it receive wholehearted support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 I would like to commend the substance of the majority bill as an obvious improvement in the development of our criminal justice relations with other nations. I have a number of concerns I would like to address in relation to aspects of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I want to answer a couple of the points made by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) when he talked about `hangers and floggers' as being the axis on which this bill rotates. Of course, there are some other issues related to the provisions of 8(1A) and 8(1B). The clause which concerns me is 8(1A) which says:

A request by a foreign country for assistance under this Act must be refused if it relates to the prosecution or punishment of a person charged with, or convicted of, an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed in the foreign country, unless the Attorney‐General is of the opinion, having regard to the special circumstances of the case, that the assistance required should be granted.

The difficulty I have with that is that it effectively places a blanket ban, with very few exceptions, on the exchange of information in a particular circumstance relating to what may have been, for instance, a particularly heinous offence. It may relate to drug trafficking offences, for instance, in the case of some of our neighbours in South‐East Asia. In my view, it effectively puts an untenable restriction on some valuable exchanges of information in relation to our own criminal justice objectives—in particular, of course, the war against drug trafficking within our nation.

If I can just make an observation, we are effectively losing the fight against the importation of illicit drugs. That has been acknowledged by a number of experts around the country, including the previous chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Tom Sherman, and a range of commentators whose expertise and knowledge is not in question. We have an extraordinary problem with the importation of drugs in this country.

In the case of Western Australia it has been calculated that each year up to $1 billion worth of illicit drugs comes across that part of the frontier that is Western Australia. There was a statistic a couple of years ago that, within a radius of 100 kilometres of Geraldton, $300 million worth of illicit drugs entered in one year. These are mind‐boggling statistics. When one considers the damage, the social effects and the dire necessity to combat this with the absolute maximum resources available to us, then quite clearly when we look at our relationship with other nations, particularly those in our region, this bill starts to take a pivotal importance in that relationship and section 8(1A) then has significance and importance in our dealings with our neighbouring countries.

We have to acknowledge that the vast proportion of illicit drugs are coming from our immediate neighbourhood. They are essentially entering our shores from our own particular region. Our regional neighbours, in many instances, are making significant attempts to combat organised drug trafficking—a highly profitable and, of course, corrupting influence—within their own countries. Obviously, this is something that troubles them, as it troubles us. It seems to me that it makes it extraordinarily difficult for Australia to be able to participate fully in a cooperative arrangement within its own region when it introduces legislation that puts a blanket ban on assistance, which includes the exchange of information, matters to do with extradition, et cetera.

The act says that assistance must be refused `if it relates to the prosecution or punishment of a person charged with, or convicted of, an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed in the foreign country'. The reason for that is that a large number of countries, not only in our region but elsewhere, still retain the death penalty on their books. Some of the states of the United States actually impose a death penalty as part of their criminal justice processes. In relation to section 8(1A), clearly this should be amended in the interests of greater international cooperation in the fight against drugs.

There are some aspects of this that may relate to the question of war crimes. As I have been advised, in relation to war crimes being dealt with by the United Nations, there are specific provisions that take away the death penalty for war crimes being investigated and subsequently prosecuted by the War Crimes Tribunal. But, as we know, that tribunal has a limited life. There are attempts to establish a standing war crimes commission but I believe that at the end of the day—I am sure there are a number of people who would agree with me—it is more likely that nations will use their own criminal justice systems to investigate, prosecute and punish those responsible, if convicted, for war crimes.

There are a number of countries in our region that are important in the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking. They include Bangladesh, Bhutan, Brunei, Cambodia, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Japan, Laos, Malaysia, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea—although it is abolitionist de facto—Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam. There is also the United States of America and, in eastern Europe, Bosnia‐Herzegovina. There are a number of others on the list but I want to deal specifically with our immediate region, for obvious reasons.

At a conference held in Sydney in 1994 on organised crime in Asia, organised jointly by the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police, there were a considerable number of complaints raised by representatives of agencies from our regional neighbours that this particular restriction—which has existed de facto up until now, and I commend the Attorney‐General for attempting to codify this in the act—has impeded better and more effective criminal investigations within our region.

I make the observation that our attitude is governed, to a certain extent, by our federal government's policy in relation to capital punishment. Of course, Australia is an abolitionist nation. Whatever one's view of capital punishment may be, the fact of the matter is that a number of our neighbouring nations have a different view. They have a view, of course, that in cases of serious drug trafficking offences capital punishment ought to be available on their statute books. It is being made available most notably in Malaysia and Thailand.

That effectively means that, in the case where a person has been arrested and prosecuted in relation to an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed, the Attorney‐General must refuse assistance. That is, in my view, a blanket ban that not only is not conducive to better and more effective criminal justice investigation relations with those neighbouring nations, but also effectively makes the Attorney‐General's position more difficult. Of course, it provides for that `unless the Attorney‐General is of the opinion, having regard to the special circumstances of the case, that the assistance requested should be granted'. In other words, the requirement is that the circumstances should be sufficiently strong for the blanket ban to be overturned.

This is a matter of some importance in the debate on the question of organised crime and drug trafficking. It is something that I think is a contentious issue. It is an issue that deserves a fuller debate. In my view, it deserves a debate in the main chamber of the House of Representatives. I believe it is important that the community sees that we are treating this matter with seriousness, that we are exploring its complete ramifications and, if and when the decision is made to amend the bill or to carry the bill in its current form, that it is made at the conclusion of a thoroughgoing and informative debate.

I for one would like to listen to the Attorney‐General's expanded views on this particular provision, so that he can explain them to members of the community, many of whom are disquieted about the international drug trafficking problem that exists in relation to our own country. I recently made a visit to Interpol and the National Criminal Intelligence Service in Britain, and know that international drug trafficking is a matter of growing concern and a matter that many leading criminal investigators from various agencies concede is causing extraordinary concerns around the world. The transnational nature of its activities makes it extraordinarily difficult for an individual nation to be able to stamp out or stop it within its own territory. That is why international cooperation and the exchange of information and evidence is absolutely critical.

Clearly, no‐one would expect the Attorney‐General to permit assistance in the case where, for instance, a country with a criminal justice system that is highly questionable was involved: where, for instance, the standards of evidence and other standards might be completely below what we would consider the acceptable minimum. Clearly, nobody would expect that to be the case. I believe, in the circumstances I have described, that with the amendment that would still be provided for. It is just that, in this particular instance, the `must' in line one of section 8(1A) is a blanket ban. It remains then for the case to be put that the special circumstances of the case are so overwhelming that that blanket ban should be overturned.

There are many people around the country who very are concerned about our problems with drug trafficking. It is safe to say that drug trafficking is at the base of much criminal activity within our country. The Economist magazine in June commented that you are more likely to be burgled, robbed or assaulted without a weapon in Australia than in the United States. For instance, in my state the statistics show that in some of the leading criminal activities the rate is almost twice the average of the Commonwealth.

If one concludes that at the base of much of our criminal activity is drug trafficking, and I suppose the associated activities in relation to drug trafficking, if we do not make the fight against drugs our number one objective we are going to see some extraordinary problems in the future—problems that will make our current situation seem small beer in comparison. Recent statistics that have been shown to me in the case of European countries show that they have seen a mushrooming of drug trafficking to an extent that is almost mind‐boggling, where criminal justice police agencies have little effect on being able to stop it or stamp it out.

We know, for instance, even where one considers changes to the law to provide for the decriminalisation of marijuana or similar proposals that some people sincerely believe will help alleviate our drug problem in Australia, that the people responsible for trafficking drugs will cynically manipulate the market to provide cheaper, more pure, other drugs—for instance, heroin. The other day we saw in Western Australia the recovery of a bag of a substantial amount of an illicit drug—believed to be cocaine—on an inbound British Airways jet that had arrived at Perth. We are now faced, along with a number of other nations, with an explosion of drug trafficking. We are faced, in the case of the prevailing budget as of last night, with very substantial cuts to the Australian Federal Police, cuts that I believe will have a deleterious effect on our fight against drug trafficking and cuts that come in conjunction with cuts in other areas in recent times, particularly the Australian Customs Service and the National Crime Authority.

In totality, these cuts are going to impede our fight against organised crime, but in particular our fight against drug trafficking. We have seen reported at the Wood royal commission the corruption of police, corruption of the judiciary, corruption of politicians and corruption of business people, and often at the base of this is the profit making that is available in the trafficking of illicit drugs. So it has a tremendous social effect.

Here we have a situation where, at this very point, we are prepared to let this particular bill travel through the Main Committee as a non‐contentious piece of legislation when section 8(1A) provides for a blanket ban on the assistance available in cases where we are dealing with a number of the nations in our region which have, in some instances, an equally strong commitment to the fight against drug trafficking. I make my case that this will impede rather than help that relationship and will not contribute to better cooperation between our countries.

Drug trafficking is an international menace. Anybody who thinks otherwise ought to think again. It is transnational. It is, in many instances, a chain that stretches around the globe. If we believe for one minute that this particular section is going to assist our opportunity to participate in an international fight against drug trafficking then we really ought to think again. And if we believe that this is non‐contentious—in other words, should travel through the Main Committee without demur—then we also, I think, are failing the community. This ought to be back in the House of Representatives main chamber and, Mr Deputy Speaker, at the conclusion I intend to move that further proceedings be conducted in the House in order that amendments may be considered.

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

—My understanding is that the question before the Chair is that the bill be read a second time. It is appropriate for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to comment. There will then be the opportunity for the Main Committee to consider the bill in detail. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments on behalf the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) will not be long but I do, on his behalf, apologise that other commitments in the House have required him to be absent from the further consideration of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Bill 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: On his behalf I thank those who have spoken: the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), the honourable member for Murray (Mrs Stone), and now the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). We welcome the support that has been offered by the opposition for the bill.

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act has been in force for almost 10 years. Clearly, as with any initiative, it is appropriate that its effectiveness and efficiency be reviewed and in that context we have this bill before us. There was wide‐ranging consultation in the review with the government, the private sector, law enforcement agencies and civil liberty groups. At the end of the day, this process has ensured that we have the best possible solutions in the form of this legislation.

The Attorney‐General is particularly grateful for the support of the opposition and the honourable member for Murray regarding the death penalty issue. The honourable member for Moore has, however, foreshadowed some concerns that he has in relation to this matter. I want to make it very clear that I do not think anybody in the parliament would demur on what he has had to say about the importance of fighting drug trafficking. The questions are: in what way do you deal with these particular issues and what impact might they have? This matter has been discussed with the Attorney‐General and I am informed that he is not prepared to agree to any amendments. Obviously, if this means the bill needs to be considered in detail in the Main Committee, that is an issue which will be addressed.

I would, however, point out to the honourable member for Moore that section 8(1A) deals with the position specifically where charges have been laid and where a person is charged with or convicted of an offence in respect of which the death penalty may be imposed. His concerns about assistance in cases where charges have not been laid are dealt with in clause 8(1B) where there is a far broader discretion to provide the assistance.

I note also that I understand the Attorney‐General, in relation to 8(1A), has a discretion to grant assistance sought if there are special circumstances in the particular case. Normally assistance would not be granted unless the requesting state gave an assurance that the death penalty, if imposed, would not be carried out. I think there is a basis for dialogue where cooperation is sought. Cooperation would only be denied if a state were not willing to give the assurance that even if the death penalty was imposed it would not be carried out. To those who are interested in this question of what the role of the state ought to be in these matters that, to my way of thinking, does not seem to be an unreasonable basis upon which to deal with this difficult issue.

The government has considered the issues raised by the honourable member for Moore. It considers that it has the right solution and would ask that he reconsider his approach in relation to this matter so we can have the legislation. If he intends to persist with his amendment obviously he will seek the referral.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1‐3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to see this particular instance becoming a debate between whether one supports the death penalty or otherwise; it is a question of whether or not the blanket ban imposed on subsection 8(1A) proposed by clause 41, as the amendment to the principal act, would in fact impede our relations with countries where the death penalty is still on the statute books.

SPEECH.PARA: I know, from having read the explanatory memorandum and from having had the opportunity of a briefing from officers of the department, that an assurance may be sought from the nation which has the particular penalty on the books that the death penalty will not be imposed. That would then be the basis on which assistance may be given.

All I am saying is that, in this particular instance, the blanket ban is the problem here. In my view, that should be changed from `must' to `may' and the last clause of section 8(1A), that is, `Unless the Attorney‐General is of the opinion. . . ' continuing until the full stop, should be deleted.

I believe that, were this to be more widely debated in the community, many people around the country would have some serious problems with it. At the end of the day, we still have the provision allowing the Attorney‐General to refuse assistance; in other words, the Attorney‐General has the discretion available to him or her. The clause then would allow for assistance without the blanket ban being applicable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond briefly. The comments I made in relation to subclause 8(1A) were that the Attorney, under that subsection, does have a discretion to grant assistance sought if there are special circumstances and normally assistance would not be granted unless the requesting state gave an assurance that the death penalty, if imposed, would not be carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances, we are in a situation where, notwithstanding the use of the word `must', there is a basis upon which cooperation can be sought, and the government considers it reasonable that the condition of the offer of that assistance is not that the country concerned changes its system of law, but that it simply gives us an assurance that the death penalty, if imposed, would not be carried out. That does not seem to be an unreasonable requirement. And if the issues that you are saying are as important to those who are investigating these matters and have brought charges, it seems to me that that cooperation, if it is important, should not be difficult to obtain.

It is in that context that we believe that this is a cooperative arrangement which can be operated to give assistance but which does not leave us in a situation where we are a party, in effect, to the application of a death penalty to people when we are in a position to aid the prosecution in relation to a particular matter. I am surprised that what is, in fact, a matter that has been the subject of very long consideration and consultation still worries the honourable member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for the concern is the onerous requirement that, when requesting assistance, a nation that is in the process of prosecuting someone is required to provide a guarantee that the death penalty will not be applied. In other words, Australia is asking that nation to adjust its criminal justice system to suit us.

SPEECH.PARA: The irony is somewhat rich. We actually helped train the troops from a neighbouring country that has recently been responsible for killing innocent citizens of its own nation. Yet here, in the case of, say, a drug trafficker who is responsible for drug trafficking, we would impose a requirement that that nation provide a guarantee that the death penalty would not be applied in that particular case. In my view, that requirement is too onerous and it is an impediment to better cooperation in our region. And let's face it, on both sides of the political process both the previous government and the current government have obviously expounded on the greater relationship with our Asian neighbours.

All I am saying is that this provision has in it an implication that we are asserting that in the case of, say, Malaysia or Singapore, aspects of their criminal justice system are so abhorrent to us that we would not cooperate in the investigation of a very serious offence. We are talking about offences ranging from murder to war crimes, and all the way through to, in some instances, very serious drug trafficking offences. My view is that at the end of the day, that would be seen to be a stumbling block in the way of better cooperative efforts at a time when we need cooperation. We do not want to put impediments in the way; we should be removing them.

At the end of the day, the Attorney‐General still has a discretion available in the amendments that I propose to move. We are not taking away that discretion. It is not a very onerous requirement to make a guarantee in relation to the prosecution of a person who has been arrested and charged with an offence in that particular category. That is all.

As far as the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) raising subsection 8(1B), I have no problem with it at all. It is just this particular section that I believe would attract a fair amount of interest and opposition from around the country from those who believe, as I do, that any of these sorts of impediments ought to be removed and that, at the end of the day, a blanket ban is not in our best interests.
