—The member for Moore knows that his remarks must be addressed through the chair. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has the call.

—The honourable member makes some comments about dealings with other nations. We don't have to be ashamed of our values in relation to these matters. Other countries understand our values in relation to these matters. They are more concerned if, in your dealings with them, you leave them in some doubt as to where you stand in relation to these matters. And the purpose of this bill is to leave other countries, within the region and elsewhere, in no doubt as to where we stand in relation to assistance. We do not want to create false expectations. We think it is far better that we be explicit about the circumstances in which Australia will assist. In that sense, the proposals that we put are ones that we would insist upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to answer a couple of those points. Firstly, I understand that the comments by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) are correct; I understand to what object this particular clause relates. I am just saying that, in this instance, I believe there should be discretion for the Attorney‐General in order to be able to consider the matter. If you look at it carefully—the wording says `unless the Attorney‐General is of the opinion, having regard to the special circumstances of the case'—there is no provision in there, in fact, for there to be a guarantee. It just mentions having regard to the special circumstances of the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The guarantee is a policy matter. It is a matter of international relations between Australia and whichever country is applicable. It does not codify there exactly what is required for the Attorney‐General to be satisfied of the special circumstances. But, from the explanatory memorandum, we know that that is in fact a guarantee by the nation concerned—the prosecuting nation—that the death penalty would not be applied in that case.

I understand also that it relates to prosecution or punishment. The punishment is a secondary issue, and that is why I would still give the discretion to the Attorney‐General. It is a question of prosecution. I add that, as the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs would know, in some of these cases during the prosecution evidence of the activities of accomplices is revealed. These might be accomplices within Australia.

It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that where there is a transnational conspiracy there is going to be the revealing of evidence that would perhaps give rise to, if the person were available, the prosecution of an Australian citizen. In that case, there is a clear provision there for the Attorney‐General to exercise his discretion. But there may also be evidence that Australians hold, or may be able to provide, that may facilitate the breaking of an international cartel of drug traffickers. It is my view that the onerous requirement imposed, not necessarily by the actual wording of the bill but by the policy statement in the explanatory memorandum, is too onerous. As a consequence, I propose the amendment.

I do not disagree with the minister. If one were to put it to a referendum, perhaps most Australians would support the abolition of the death penalty. I am sure they would support Australia's general policy to support its abolition wherever it can. But, at the same time, I think that there would be many in the community—I believe it would be the majority—who would also see an impedance like this as being outside that particular objective.

BREAK.PARA: After all, this bill is designed to be a bill on mutual assistance in criminal matters, not a policy of Australia on trying to further its own particular conviction that capital punishment ought to be abolished. This is where we are endeavouring to arrive at agreements with other countries as to assistance relating to criminal investigation and criminal prosecutions. I repeat: all I am saying is that the blanket ban and the onerous requirement in the final clause of that particular section are an impedance. I am yet to be convinced by the minister at the table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear that the honourable member is not convinced, and I am not endeavouring to join issue on every point that he makes, because I think I dealt with most of them before and there is a degree of repetition.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other sections, as I indicated, in which cooperation can be sought. In relation to the conspiracy argument possibly involving Australians, section 8(1A) would not arise. We are dealing with a situation in which people would then be dealt with under our law. The application of our law in relation to the use of the evidence and information that we might have would be in relation to a prosecution of people here. So I do not understand the connection that the honourable member is trying to make regarding the argument of conspiracy.

I will contain my remarks, save to emphasise that the honourable member is seeking to use discretionary words in relation to the general principle. The discretion is, in fact, obtained through the special circumstances in a particular case. As has been noted, where assistance will be offered is where a state has agreed that, if a prosecution which involves the death penalty is secured, an assurance that the death penalty will not be carried out will be sufficient to secure the cooperation.

That does not seem to be at all unreasonable. It does involve an element of discretion that can be obtained through the willingness of two states to cooperate. I do not think the divisions are very significant. I am surprised that the member wants to persist with the matter, given what is said in the explanatory memorandum and the way in which the particular clause has been drafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1 be agreed to. All those of that opinion say aye, or to the contrary, no. I think the ayes have it.

—No, the ayes have it. There is no facility for a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will of course not be opposing the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. Why would we? It is exactly the same bill that we introduced when in government in November last year. This debate also provides me with an opportunity to reflect briefly on the work and the contribution made by the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca. Regrettably, whilst Australia remembered in 1995, in 1996 they seem to have forgotten Con in his own electorate. I think it is one of the great pities of the recent election loss for the Australian Labor Party that Con Sciacca was not returned to this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have been travelling around, both in the company of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) and, indeed, on my own, from talking to people in the veterans community I have been absolutely staggered and overwhelmed by the comments made by the veterans in respect of the contribution made by Con Sciacca.

TALK.START.PARA: —They adore him.

—As my colleague rightly interjects, they in fact do adore him and in veterans' affairs that is not a state in which one easily finds oneself. I think that Con proved himself to be someone who was prepared to listen and mix and to fight battles on behalf of the veterans community. For those very reasons he was, and continues to be, much loved.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that, in considering the legislation before the committee today, we again pay tribute to the work that Con did as minister: it was, after all, his legislation. I certainly commend the present government for continuing with this matter and for bringing it forward. As we have seen, there is absolutely no disagreement between the government and the opposition in respect of it.

The document itself, as was commented in the explanatory memorandum, actually gives effect to two particular matters. The first element is to amend the Defence Service Homes Act of 1918 and to incorporate certain provisions of the consumer credit code that is to be adopted by state and territory governments during the course of this year. It is also going to allow defence service homes scheme beneficiaries rights under the consumer credit code for matters not specified in this amending bill. The second element of this legislation is to amend the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986, to streamline the granting of a pension to a dependant of a veteran who dies from a war‐caused injury or disease.

Let me take the second of those amendments first and comment briefly. I do not think that any member of parliament who has contact with the veterans community would not be aware of the trauma for many veterans in proving that illness, or some debilitation, is war related. Then, after they have succeeded in doing so, when they pass away their dependant is faced with that same element of proof. This amendment removes that. This amendment says that once it has been established that a veteran is entitled to some form of assistance, some pension, some entitlement under the veterans' affairs legislation and—having proved that beyond all reasonable doubt—is granted that entitlement, then the dependant of that veteran is similarly given that entitlement on the death of the applicant.

PARA.TAB: This is very significant and very important. It removes trauma. It is going to take away the difficulties often confronting dependants who have gone through the process of establishing an entitlement and receiving the benefit, together with the person in receipt of the benefit, but who then have that lifelong partner pass away. They are faced with the double whammy, if you like, of firstly having to cope with that and then having to go through the process again of establishing an entitlement. To remove that trauma is very important.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Slipper interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) interjects, it would be more difficult, once the original veteran who was given the entitlement passes away, to prove that.

BREAK.PARA: I commend the government for adopting this measure, which was put in place and brought forward last year by the former government and by the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and I congratulate the government for continuing to ensure that veterans and, more importantly with this particular provision, their dependants, are given care, comfort and support.

The second issue concerns the amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918. We know that consumer issues in financial services are ones which are very near and dear to the hearts of all of us. We are all consumers at the end of the day. It does not matter if you are a veteran, it does not matter if you are a member of parliament. What you want to know and what you want to be protected by are some guarantees in consumer codes in respect of all of your transactions with financial institutions.

That is particularly so in respect of the purchase of homes. After all, for most people the purchase of a home is in fact the acquiring of the largest asset that they are ever going to make a commitment for. One would hope, therefore, that when making that commitment they are given appropriate consumer guidance and that the decisions they make and any contractual obligations they enter into have force of law and, importantly, bring consumer benefits.

This amendment to the Defence Service Homes Act will give those additional benefits that states and territories are now adopting in respect of the Consumer Credit Code. Again I commend the government for bringing this forward as part of this legislation. It again follows on from legislation which the former government introduced last year.

It is interesting, however, when in the context of last night's budget announcements one goes to budget statements and Budget Paper No. 1 to look at this issue of defence service homes. I want to raise very quickly one or two matters out of that, and would hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs might take on board a couple of the questions I am going to pose now because I think the veterans community would certainly like to hear from the minister on these matters.

At page 3‐126 of Budget Paper No. 1 there is reference to defence service homes in the forward estimates for 1996‐97. If one looks at the 1996‐97 budget, one sees that it is suggested that some $50.9 million will be made available for defence service homes but that in fact is a reduction of 1.4 per cent. Fortunately, in 1997‐98 the estimated expenditure in the forward estimates is going up again to $55.3 million, which estimates an 8.6 per cent increase, but it is estimated that in 1998‐99 expenditure will decrease again to $53.2 million, a reduction of 3.8 per cent. It is to go up marginally, by 0.8 per cent, to $53.6 million, according to the forward estimates for the 1999‐2000 budget.

It strikes me that this is a bit of a roller‐coaster ride. Perhaps it reflects trends in the marketplace which the Department of Veterans' Affairs is aware of. If that is the case, then obviously there is no concern and no cause for alarm. It is incumbent upon us—and I am speaking now as a member of parliament who will be approached by members of the veterans community rather than as the shadow minister—to know what this means and whether a smoothing out effect will ultimately occur. What that probably does reflect, as I have speculated, is changes in demand of the use of the program at different times, or perhaps interest rate fluctuations which the government is banking on. I am not sure whether that roller‐coaster ride over the next four years indicates when interest rates are likely to go up or come down—perhaps we might look at that a little more closely and all race out and purchase property! It is an issue that is of concern. I ask the minister to give us a response to that.

Similarly, at page 3‐127 of Budget Paper No. 1, under subprogram 7.2, `Defence Service Homes', it is noted under `home acquisition assistance' that the budget for 1996‐97 is $54.3 million, which represents a two per cent decrease on 1995‐96. Again, however, one sees a reflection of the roller‐coaster ride factor, which I mentioned with regard to the forward estimates, in that it is proposed that the amount increases by 7.2 per cent in 1997‐98, decreases by 1.2 per cent in 1998‐99, and increases by 0.9 per cent in the 1999‐2000 budget. I guess this reflects something of demand again. However, it would be appreciated if the minister could give us some indication about that so that the veterans community, and members of parliament who counsel veterans about these issues, will be better informed.

The other thing which is of concern to us all is the decision taken by the government to extract from departments a two per cent across‐the‐board running cost reduction. The minister could suggest to us what that might mean in terms of delivery of services by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to that very important group in the community that is in need of special care and assistance.

I understand that potentially we are going to see something like a 10 per cent reduction in staffing within the Department of Veterans' Affairs as a result of the decision that the government has taken to reduce running costs. I understand that one way in which departments have approached that—and we have seen headlines about it—is by cutting staff numbers. I appreciate that a simple way of doing that within departments is to follow that principle and shed staff. I would caution the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in looking at ways to achieve cost‐cutting measures, to reflect upon the delivery mechanism that might be impacted upon by such a decision.

This cost cutting is imposed by the government. Make no mistake about it, the government says there has to be a two per cent reduction in running costs and the simple way to do that is to cut staff numbers. Obviously, the Department of Veterans' Affairs cannot be immune from that if it is to meet that objective. However, the close relationship between the staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the veterans community is more than simply a client‐service provider relationship. It is much closer than that. If you talk to any veteran about it, he will tell you how important it is to have access to people within the department.

I hope a reduction in service will not be brought about by this decision. We must not impede the ability of the department to continue to deliver services to the veterans community. It is too important generally, across a whole range of programs, for that to occur. I again raise that as an allied issue associated with this particular piece of legislation that is before us today.

I conclude by again commending the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Con Sciacca, for his work in this portfolio. I congratulate the present minister, Mr Scott, for maintaining the commitment of this parliament, and not just the government, to the veterans community. Veterans' affairs is very much a bipartisan area. Regrettably, there are too few of those areas of bipartisanship that we can all reflect upon with some pride and sense of joy. When matters such as this are addressed by budgets or through legislation, we should not be afraid of coming out and commending the present government for any initiatives that it brings forward. I am doing so, and I wish this legislation a speedy passage through the House. I know it is supported by everybody and, as a consequence, wish it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment briefly on the remarks made by the shadow minister concerning the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca. Like many other people in the House, I had a very warm and high regard for Con and the way in which he carried out his duties as Minister for Veterans' Affairs in a bipartisan way. I am well aware of the fact that on Remembrance Day last year he came to my electorate, opening a memorial walkway in Caloundra. As he recognised, the Sunshine Coast is not a hotbed of Labor support, and was never likely to be, yet he came to my area, as minister. I know that his visit was very warmly received by members of the veterans community.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish Con a long and happy retirement outside politics. I am quite certain that he will be as successful in the business community, post‐politics, as indeed he was prior to entering parliament. I knew Con prior to his entry into politics, when both he and I were solicitors in Queensland. As I said, I wish him well in the future and certainly believe that he has the capacity to make a very great contribution to the business community.

Having said that, I am confident that the honourable member for Bowman (Mrs West), who was elected on 2 March, will do a wonderful job for a very long time on behalf of her constituents. While I have been very generous with my comments on Mr Sciacca and his performance as Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I was very pleased to see the honourable member for Bowman win her seat as part of the landslide on 2 March.

As the shadow minister indicated, this is largely a bipartisan area. I think it was one of the wartime Labor prime ministers who in effect said it was important—these are my words—that a grateful nation should be as generous as it possibly can be to those to whom we owe so much. I know over the years there has been a feeling in the veterans community from time to time that governments have not done as much as they should have done. I remember when I was in the parliament in the 1980s that there was a very great concern that the then Labor government was going to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs or maybe merge it with the Department of Social Security. That was a matter of great concern for many. Fortunately that issue worked its way through and that amalgamation never came to fruition. We now have a situation where both sides of politics recognise the important work done on behalf of the veterans community by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The previous minister should be commended on this bill, as indeed should his successor, because this is important legislation; legislation which will ensure that veterans continue to get a fair go from those who owe them so much. After all, as a nation, we enjoy freedom, stability and a way of life that is the envy of people throughout the world. I hate to think what would have been the situation in Australia if it had not been for the contribution made by those who now form part of our veterans community.

BREAK.PARA: As was mentioned by the shadow minister, there are two arms to this legislation. The first arm relates to amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 which will ensure that, if it has been established that a veteran suffered from an injury or disease that was war caused, then the death of that veteran will also be taken to be war caused. I interjected on the shadow minister to point out how difficult it has been for dependants to prove that a death was war caused after the veteran has passed on. A primary source of evidence is lost, causing dependants to have to argue these cases before the tribunals.

This has been unfair and the legislation incorporating this change is very important. It brings a new level of fairness to the dependants of veterans and so I commend the government for ensuring that if a veteran has died from an injury or disease that has already been determined by the Repatriation Commission to be war caused, then that death is to be taken to have been war caused also.

A large number of people have contacted me, in my capacity as the member for Fisher, in relation to aspects of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Now that this problem is being remedied many of my constituents will be very pleased.

The second arm of the legislation relates to amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918. The Defence Service Homes Act is being amended to incorporate certain provisions of the Consumer Credit Code that will come into effect on 1 November 1996. Over the years there has been, quite appropriately in my view, increasing emphasis on the rights of consumers and the need to be fair to consumers. As the shadow minister pointed out, all Australians are consumers, and it is very important that consumers are protected under the laws of this land.

I am pleased that the states and territories have been able to negotiate and achieve a situation where we are able to have a uniform Consumer Credit Code. It is appropriate that after the code comes into force those people eligible for housing assistance under the defence service homes scheme will gain consumer rights comparable to those of other borrowers. I do not think any reasonable person in the community—certainly nobody in the parliament—is suggesting that that should not be the case.

One fairly important aspect of the Consumer Credit Code addressed by the bill is the payment of loan interest subsidy to the Westpac Banking Corporation, which provides defence service home loans to veterans and other eligible people under an agreement with the Commonwealth. Prior to this arrangement being entered into with the Westpac Banking Corporation, loans were made directly by the Commonwealth to veterans. The former government made a positive move when it effectively contracted these matters out to the Westpac Bank and I am pleased that that bank is going to continue to provide subsidised defence service home loans.

I have had a number of complaints from veterans who say that perhaps the level of the loan has not been increased in line with the increases in the prices of homes over the years. Once, of course, a defence service home loan could be the primary source of finance for a home buyer, but in more recent times that has not been the case. The Commonwealth currently pays the subsidy in advance. Under the code the subsidy will be paid in arrears and the Commonwealth will make a one‐off saving of some $4 million. The changes made pursuant to this legislation are very important. It is also important that the Westpac Bank has agreed that it will grant all existing loan borrowers the same rights, effectively, as will apply to new loan borrowers; that is, people will have the opportunity to have the daily balance method of interest calculation.

During my years of legal practice I have had to review mortgages that people have previously entered into, and it has been a source of concern to me that at times these mortgages provided for interest to be paid not necessarily at monthly rests but at three‐monthly rests or six‐monthly rests and sometimes even at annual rests. That has meant, in many cases, that if a person is a day or two late in making a payment, another three, six or 12 months interest was paid to the mortgagee as a windfall.

I do not think that any reasonable person in a society could suggest that that was a reasonable situation. So I am very pleased that not only will new loan borrowers be protected by the Consumer Credit Code but also the Westpac Bank, while it was under no obligation to do so, has agreed—presumably in the interests of simplification but I hope also in the interests of equity and fairness—to extend this right of a daily balance method of interest calculation to existing borrowers.

It is interesting that the amendments currently being proposed will postpone slightly the date by which this new method of calculating interest on loans will apply to existing borrowers. Originally the date when this was to happen was either the uniform Consumer Credit Code commencement date or 1 November 1996. This has now been extended to 1 June 1997. There obviously could be a small number of borrowers who might be adversely affected by the delay in this change, but I consider that the overwhelming benefit of helping all existing borrowers to have a daily form of calculation probably well and truly outweighs the minor inconvenience to some as a result of the delay in implementation of this very positive move.

I would like to commend not only the former government but also the current government and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) on supporting this legislation. It is important legislation for the veterans community. As a nation we must be as generous as we can to those who have served this nation and have ensured that as a country we are really one of the most fortunate places in the world in which to live.

Prior to resuming my seat, though, I would like to touch briefly on matters just mentioned in passing by the shadow minister when he referred to budget estimates. The shadow minister probably provided his own explanation of the varying amounts of money which will be made available in relation to certain expenditure of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The fact of the matter is that the minister has been able to go in there and has been able to fight on behalf of the veterans community and I think the veterans community by and large would be very pleased with what is included in the budget.

We, as a government, inherited a black hole of $10.3 thousand million—$10.3 billion—and clearly this government is determined that for the first time in 13 years there should be a return to responsible economic management. Thus the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the budget handed down in fact found savings of well over $7 billion. I think that the veterans community and we as members of parliament should be very pleased that the veterans budget has been kept largely intact.

Certainly, as the shadow minister mentioned, there has been a two per cent reduction, but then I understand that that reduction has been applied across the board. It should be appropriate for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to look very closely at its budget and, in doing so, it should ensure that there is no reduction in services of a substantial nature to the veterans community.

I can understand that the shadow minister might not like the two per cent reduction. Perhaps none of us like the fact that there has been a two per cent reduction, but the simple fact of the matter is that the former government, prior to the election, told us that, effectively, the budget situation was that it was in surplus. We came into office, we inherited this massive great big Beazley black hole of $10.3 thousand million and obviously as a government we had to—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's wide‐ranging debate is getting miles away from the amending bill that is before the chair. I ask the honourable member to come back to the point that is before the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I just want to point out, though, that you gave a very wide‐ranging indulgence to the shadow minister. He mentioned the two per cent reduction and I was, therefore, on behalf of the government, explaining how this—

—Order! I think I have given the honourable member full range to answer the shadow minister's comments, and I think the honourable member is now ranging very wide on the subject matter before the chair. I do ask him to come back to the matter that is before the chair.

—This is very positive legislation. As I indicated earlier, there are two arms to this bill—amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Both sides of politics agree with these amendments, which will ensure that, if a veteran has died from an injury or disease that has already been determined by the Repatriation Commission to be war caused, then the death will be taken to have been war caused also. Obviously, as I mentioned just a moment ago, the amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act will bring the benefits of the Consumer Credit Code not only to new borrowers under the defence service home loan arrangements but also to existing borrowers. I commend the bill to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) and, without wishing to be too repetitive, I intend to be equally brief. I support the bill on the same basis that it was supported by the previous speakers, notably the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). It was a fine piece of Labor reform to veterans' affairs legislation which was introduced by the former federal government in November of last year. The underlying thrust of the bill is to safeguard the interests of veterans and their families and to minimise any action needed to grant certain claims for pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill does this by giving effect to two fundamental pieces of veterans' affairs legislation, one of which relates, as has been stated by previous speakers, to the amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918, which ensure that loan beneficiaries under this defence service homes scheme will have consumer rights similar, if not identical, to those of other borrowers. They will have those when all state and territory governments adopt the common Consumer Credit Code.

PARA.TAB: This amendment will also incorporate provisions of the code that are to be adopted by all state and territory governments throughout the course of this year and will give the defence service home beneficiaries rights under this code for matters not specified in the amending bill. Subsidised defence service home loans are available to veterans and other eligible people under a contractual arrangement, as has been alluded to by the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), between the Commonwealth and Westpac Banking Corporation. The bill identifies sections of that code that Westpac should not apply to such loans in order to preserve the scheme's benefits, and they are detailed in full in the bill.

For example, one of those would include a veteran's age affecting his opportunity to get a loan elsewhere. That must be taken into account, for example, if and when the bank decides whether to provide the veteran with such a defence service home loan. As was put by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) in his second reading speech, the concurrent operation of the Consumer Credit Code will not be limited, except for matters set out in the bill. This particular aspect of the legislation goes also to the question of interest charges on loans and, as has been quite clearly submitted to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that will be linked to daily balances instead of monthly balances.

BREAK.PARA: In moving amongst members of the veterans community, I know that veterans fully support the concept of ongoing housing assistance. In a survey undertaken by the previous federal government throughout the course of last year, such assistance was rated particularly highly by all the veterans groups which were surveyed. I know that younger clients, and specifically serving members, were less likely at that time to rate the existing housing arrangements as good because it was their view that increased loan amounts and interest payment subsidies to veterans are the most important improvements. I urge the government to pursue those improvements as a matter of ongoing reform.

As put to me by veterans, subsidised loans for both home modification and rent assistance are currently important. They will, I am sure, remain important in the minds of veterans and perhaps become increasingly important over the course of the next five or 10 years, during which time subsidised loans—for example, for retirement village accommodation—and the extension of loans to cover other types of housing will also increase in importance.

Equally briefly, the other aspect of veterans legislation to which this bill proposes amendment is that going to the issue of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and it has been quite clearly put by both the member for Cunningham and the member for Fisher. The amendment to this legislation relates to the dependant of a veteran who dies from a war‐caused disability becoming eligible for a pension without the need for the service relationship to be re‐established. This, of course, will streamline the granting of a pension to a dependant of a veteran who dies from a war‐caused injury or disease, and will eliminate the very time consuming and often stressful task of retracing a veteran's war service injury and illness in order to establish those links.

I know that veterans are also very supportive of the pensions process operating under the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and they deem in general that it and the appeals process are fair. Some may consider from time to time that the appeals process is a little awkward to follow and perhaps difficult to understand—which may prevent some veterans from applying or from appealing against certain decisions. Once again, those veterans appeals processes may be a matter that the current federal government could undertake to investigate and assess. I know that those veterans who do apply, and who often subsequently submit appeals, do so on the basis that they may, for example, be motivated by more than one factor. While most veterans apply because of an increasing disability—and often the underlying basis of many appeals is that that disability is not recognised—another key motivation is a sense that they deserve and need more money to get by on.

In conclusion, this piece of what is effectively Labor legislation is commended to the Committee on the basis that it is a necessary piece of reform. I congratulate both the much loved previous minister, Con Sciacca, and the current minister for proceeding to implement it. I know that, as I move about in the electorate of Isaacs, some of the clubs in that electorate—including Mentone, Edithvale, Aspendale, Chelsea, Carrum and Cranbourne—provide a great service to veterans, young and old. It is on behalf of those veterans, members of those clubs—who fought so bravely in so many theatres of war around the world for the freedom of our great country, and with whom I recently remembered and commemorated the diggers who fought so heroically and so inspirationally 30 years ago during the tragic battle of Long Tan—that I support the bill. I know that those diggers would also urge me to support this bill. It is on that basis that I commend it to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I speak in support of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). I am sure its passage will be greeted with some relief by veterans throughout Australia. Schedule 1 of the bill ensures that there is greater equity for loan beneficiaries under the defence service homes scheme to have the same consumer rights as those enjoyed by the broader community. In the words of the explanatory memorandum to the legislation, `any potential conflict' between the Defence Services Homes Act 1918 and the consumer credit legislation will also be removed. With the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Westpac Banking Corporation, the bank will advance home loans to those deemed eligible under the Defence Services Homes Act 1918.

SPEECH.PARA: In a related development, all state and territory governments have agreed to enact legislation for a consumer credit code during 1996. This code applies to all credit provided in the course of business of a credit provider to a borrower who is an individual or strata corporation and if the credit is provided wholly or predominantly for personal, domestic or household purposes. The bill ensures that Westpac Banking Corporation's legal obligations under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 largely comply with the requirements of the Consumer Credit Code.

These changes will come into effect from 1 November this year. After this time, people eligible for housing assistance under the defence services homes scheme will gain consumer rights comparable with those of other borrowers.

Schedule 2 of the act is what I consider to be a very important piece of legislation that corrects some ambiguities of the 1986 Veterans' Entitlements Act. It will mean that the dependants of a veteran who has died from a disability already accepted as war‐caused will be eligible for a pension without the relationship between the veteran's death and the war service having to be re‐established. A claim for a pension by or for a dependant of a veteran who died from a war‐caused injury or disease will be granted immediately, once the connection is identified, without reference to the statement of principles.

Because claims for dependant pensions have to be determined by the statement of principles and prepared by the repatriation medical authority, often with additional investigation, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has commented:
A veteran's death from a war‐caused disability is now no guarantee that his or her dependants will have access to repatriation benefits.

He has also said that `this uncertainty is unacceptable' and that the changes brought about by this legislation `will reassure veterans and their families that financial support will continue to be available should a veteran die from a previously accepted, war‐caused disability.' At a time of bereavement, obviously this will be a huge relief for the families involved.

The RSL has written to me stating that `this is a considerable win for the RSL and the veteran community.' As the RSL has also said, credit is due to Dr Allan Hawke, former secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and the former minister, Con Sciacca, who initiated this corrective action.

BREAK.PARA: I have had my attention drawn to a situation where the passing away of a veteran resulted in the war widows pension to the surviving dependant being held up and put in jeopardy until she submitted a new claim. This must have been a very stressful time for her. This legislation will ensure that such an unfortunate situation will not repeat itself.

As has already been said by other speakers in the Committee today, the veterans community is important to us. We were, of course, reminded of that very much last year during Australia Remembers. I do commend Con Sciacca, as others have done today, particularly for the part that he played in that commemoration. As the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) said, Con Sciacca did achieve a bipartisan approach. I found him to be a minister that one could approach in the corridor and say that some veteran needed some attention. He would say, `Put it in writing,' and the matter seemed to get fixed.

So that was a good reminder last year. Last Sunday the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and I were at the same function where I was representing the minister—whom I am pleased to see has arrived in the Committee—at the unveiling and dedication of the Korea‐South‐East Asia memorial. Of course, that was a particularly important day for Vietnam veterans because the memorial was unveiled on the 30th anniversary of the battle of Long Tan when Australian soldiers displayed the same courage and heroism as others had displayed in previous wars.

TALK.START.PARA: —The memorial had its genesis in Australia Remembers.

—It certainly did. In fact, I pay tribute to the Mayor of Hindmarsh and Woodville, John Dyer, who initiated the whole idea. It came to fruition recently and it is quite a monument. I was certainly pleased to have been associated with the unveiling. I know, of course, that the minister was in Vietnam that very same day with veterans that he had accompanied there.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to mention that there is another issue that the previous minister charged me to do something about and about which I have been in contact more recently with the current minister. That is doing something about the fact that there is no memorial to the ex‐servicewomen in South Australia or certainly not in Adelaide. We are working on that now, Minister, not only with your cooperation, but with the cooperation of the state government and the Adelaide City Council. I think the veterans community enjoys bipartisan support. That is the way it should be. We all owe them a great deal. People from both sides of the chamber have taken part in this debate and I welcome the positive change it will bring to the lives of veterans and their families to whom this country owes a great debt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to, firstly, in summing up, thank the members from both sides of the parliament for their contribution to this bill. It is an important bill. Although for many it may seem that minor amendments are being made, they are, nonetheless, very important and significant to the veteran community.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation was introduced into the House on 22 May and at the end of the day the changes it proposes will safeguard the interests of veterans and their families and minimise action needed to grant claims for pensions.

I would like to run through some of the issues that were raised during the debate, referring firstly to the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) and his contribution. Before dealing in detail with the contribution by the shadow minister, I would like to say that he accompanied me to Australia Remembers and Revisits Vietnam 30 Years On in Vietnam last week. He was certainly a valuable contributor to the commemoration program. I was pleased to see that the honourable member for Cunningham was able to be part of that very important and historic visit to Vietnam.

I will be presenting a report to the parliament in the next sitting on the visit to Vietnam, so I will not go into any great detail on that, but I thank the honourable member for Cunningham for his participation in what was indeed an historic and memorable commemoration in Vietnam.

The honourable member for Cunningham sought comments on budget items on page 3‐126 with reference to the defence service home forward estimates jumping up and down. This really is quite normal under the circumstances and has quite a lot to do with the way the loans are now calculated. They used to be paid in advance and now will be paid in arrears. So that reflects the different method which this bill is going to allow to happen.

In some cases, also, loans are being paid out by veterans and obviously new ones are being taken out and changed around in that manner. That means that these payments will be reflected in the manner in which people are utilising the facility. I hope that gives the honourable member for Cunningham some understanding of why those figures do vary and are not consistent from year to year.

The same applies to his second question relating to page 3‐127, which refers to home acquisition assistance. There is obviously a flow‐on effect from the way the interest subsidy used to be paid in advance and is now going to be in arrears. So there is a flow‐on effect to that second question.

In terms of the decision to save two per cent across the board, the member for Cunningham asked whether it equalled a 10 per cent reduction in staffing and what impact it would have on veterans. I appreciate his comments in terms of the importance of the department's staff. I have certainly had—wherever I have been—wonderful support from the department's staff.

They do an excellent job and they are extremely well received by the veteran community, and that is a great credit to the department. Bureaucrats are often criticised by the general population. This is not the case with the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and I know that the veterans themselves have a very close association with the staff of the department.

The member for Cunningham asked, `Does the decision to save two per cent across the board equate to a 10 per cent cut in staffing?' Well, whilst we are looking at doing things smarter and thinking smarter about the delivery of programs in the future, it is not all about cutting staff. It is certainly about cutting out unnecessary waste. It is also about improved technology, which can often lead to doing things better. It is often, in some cases, possible to buy a service rather than be a service deliverer.

So, whilst the two per cent across‐the‐board savings are very important in terms of the context of the budget, there is not always a 10 per cent reduction in staff as the Community and Public Sector Union—I was thinking of that other group of unions that was bashing on the doors of Parliament House earlier this week—would have you believe. Let me assure the member for Cunningham that any savings are designed to create a more efficient department; they are not going to be at the expense of delivering the best possible service to the veterans to whom this nation owes a great debt of gratitude. It is a debt that I do not believe will ever adequately be repaid, but it is one that we must continue to honour. So let me assure the shadow minister of that.

BREAK.PARA: There is one little thing that I would say to the shadow minister—I see him walking into the Main Committee room. One of the things that I have been told by members of the veteran community is that they really do object to being referred to as `clients'. They really would like to be called `veterans' rather than `clients' and I am encouraging my department to use the word `veteran' rather than `client'. I know it is difficult at times. I know it is very difficult to describe people: are they `clients', `customers' or `veterans'? But it is one thing that I ask all members of parliament, on both sides, to look at where possible, as the use of `veteran' might be far more acceptable to this very deserving section of our Australian community.

The member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and the member for Cunningham both commended the previous minister on his work as Minister for Veterans' Affairs. On a number of occasions, when addressing ex‐service organisations' annual meetings around this country, I have also commended the previous minister on the work he did in the portfolio. I will not go on any further now, but I thank them for those very sincere comments on the previous minister's work in this portfolio. They were reflected on both sides of the parliament. I think it reflects a genuine desire in the parliament to be as bipartisan as possible with the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs. That does not mean to say that we are not going to, from time to time, have some disagreement on issues. But I do note that both the member for Cunningham and the member for Fisher commended Con Sciacca on the work that he did in the portfolio.

In conclusion, I want to acknowledge the work that all members in this House do for the veterans in their communities. I know that this nation is still in debt to the veterans, both young and old, for the manner in which they gave us this great freedom. This democracy we all enjoy came at a price. We must continue to support our veterans. I thank members on both sides of the House for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Extradition Arrangements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With which countries in its neighbourhood does Australia have extradition arrangements.
(2) On what date did each arrangement come into force.

(3) Has he or his Department initiated discussions about extradition arrangements with countries other than those referred to in part (1) : if so (a) with which countries, (b) upon what dates and (c) with what results.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Australia is able to grant extradition to countries to which the Extradition Act 1988 applies. Application of the Extradition Act to a country gives legal force in Australia to extradition arrangements concluded by Australia with another country. These arrangements are of different kinds, with bilateral treaties being only one example. Thus the Extradition Act may be applied to give effect to bilateral extradition treaties, various `less than treaty status' arrangements, British extradition treaties dating from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries inherited by Australia, and extradition obligations arising under multilateral conventions.
I am advised that the question concerns Australia's general extradition arrangements with the ASEAN countries and countries in the Western Pacific region.
ASEAN
The ASEAN countries include Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei Darussalam, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam.

Australia's extradition arrangements with Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei Darussalam are governed by the Commonwealth Scheme for the Rendition of Fugitive Offenders, the London Scheme. An extradition arrangement under the London Scheme is a `less than treaty status' arrangement under which the extradition laws of one Commonwealth country are applied to the other in the absence of a treaty. Malaysia, Singapore and Brunei Darussalam are declared under the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Regulations to be extradition countries for the purposes of the Extradition Act. Australia's extradition laws were applied to Malaysia and Singapore on 1 May 1967 and to Brunei Darussalam on 3 May 1985.
Australia has a non-treaty extradition arrangement with Thailand. The Extradition Act was applied to Thailand in the absence of a treaty on 6 December 1995.
Australia has a modern bilateral extradition treaty with Indonesia. The Treaty was signed at Jakarta on 22 April 1992 and came into force on 21 January 1995.
Australia also has a modern extradition treaty with the Philippines. That Treaty was signed at Manila on 7 March 1988 and came into force on 18 January 1991.
Australia has no bilateral extradition relationship with Vietnam.
Western Pacific Region

Most of the countries in the Western Pacific region are Commonwealth countries. Australia's extradition arrangements with those countries are governed by the London Scheme and the Extradition Act applies to such countries under the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Regulations on a non-treaty basis. Examples of Commonwealth countries with such extradition arrangements include the Cook Islands, Western Samoa, Tonga, Vanuatu, Kiribati, Nauru, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. Australian extradition laws were applied to Western Samoa, Kiribati, Nauru, the Solomon Islands and Tonga on 17 December 1970, to Papua New Guinea on 28 November 1975, to Vanuatu on 3 May 1985 and to the Cook Islands on 27 May 1992.

Australia has a non-treaty extradition arrangement with Fiji and the Marshall Islands. Previously, the Extradition Act applied to Fiji under the London Scheme. Some time after Fiji left the Commonwealth, the Extradition Act was applied to the Republic of Fiji on 23 May 1991 under the Extradition (Republic of Fiji) Regulations. Australia's extradition laws were applied to the Marshall Islands in the absence of a treaty on 30 June 1993.

Australia has a modern extradition treaty with France which entered into force on 23 November 1989. That Treaty facilitates extradition between Australia and French territories in the Pacific, such as French Polynesia and New Caledonia.

All extradition treaties and arrangements between Australia and other countries operate subject to Australia's Extradition Act 1988. The Extradition Act creates a mechanism for the processing of extradition requests in Australia. The Act sets out the matters that Australian courts have to consider before ruling on a person's eligibility for extradition. The Act also sets out the matters that the Attorney-General must consider in deciding whether a person is to be surrendered to another country. The Act contains all the internationally-accepted human rights safeguards that are now a part of modern extradition.

(3) The question seeks information about extradition discussions initiated with other countries in the region. Extradition discussions with another country are aimed at establishing an extradition treaty with that country. It is not appropriate to disclose this due to the international practice that bilateral treaty negotiations are considered confidential between the parties until such time as a treaty is signed. This practice of not publicising bilateral treaty negotiations is recognised in the Government's recently announced policy on greater Parliamentary involvement in Australia's treaty‐making processes. Consequently, it is not appropriate for me to identify countries with which Australia is currently negotiating extradition arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Maintenance and Child Abduction Conventions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he bring up‐to‐date the information contained in the answer to question No. 1238 (Hansard , 28 June 1994, page 2175) on maintenance and child abduction.
(2) Has he initiated discussions with other countries on these issues; if so, (a) with which countries, (b) upon what dates and (c) with what results.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 2 June 1994, the following states have become parties, by accession, to the 1956 UN Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance, done at New York on 26 June 1956:
Ireland—26 October 1995; Uruguay—18 September 1995
Since 2 June 1994, the following states have accepted the Statute of the Hague Conference on Private International Law, done at The Hague on 31 October 1951:
Croatia—12 June 1995 (by succession); Malta—30 January 1995

Following is a list of states which, being members of the Hague Conference, have ratified, accepted or approved the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, done at The Hague on 25 October 1980, or, not being members of the Hague Conference, have acceded to the Convention, since 2 June 1994:
Since 2 June 1994 the following accessions to the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction have been accepted by Australia:
Bahamas, Honduras and Panama—13 June 1994 with effect 1 Sep 1994
Chile and Slovenia—17 Aug 1994 with effect 1 Nov 1994
Cyprus and Saint Kitts & Nevis—18 Aug 1995 with effect 1 Nov 1995
Zimbabwe—18 Jan 1996 with effect 1 April 1996

(2) I have not initiated any discussions with other countries in relation to the 1956 UN Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance. Issues relating to maintenance are the responsibility of the Attorney‐General. I understand that the Attorney‐General's Department has been undertaking negotiations by correspondence on bilateral arrangements concerning maintenance with Germany, Norway, Finland, Greece and Quebec (Canada). New bilateral maintenance arrangements have been agreed with the Czech Republic, the Republic of Ireland and the Slovak Republic.

In relation to the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since 1992 the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has regularly made representations to other countries encouraging them to become parties to the Convention in order to facilitate the speedy resolution of any future child abduction incidents in countries in our immediate region, or countries which have been major migrant source countries.

(a) Australian posts have made representations to the following countries in the Asia/Pacific region: the Philippines, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Tonga, the Solomon Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, Western Samoa, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Burma, India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Pakistan. Representations have more recently been made to the following countries with high numbers of dual citizens in Australia: Turkey, Lebanon, Russia and South Africa.

(b) Representations have been made in September 1992, November 1993, April and September 1994 and February and March 1996, although not all of the countries listed above have received representations on all of these occasions.

(c) The process of representations encouraging countries to become parties to the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has been protracted. For many countries this is a new and unfamiliar issue and does not carry the same degree of priority or domestic urgency as in Australia. For example, some countries, particularly those having a religious basis to family law, view the Convention as inappropriate to their interests. Nevertheless, we have recently received indications that three of the countries listed above are positively disposed to the Convention and are likely to become parties once domestic legislation has been implemented, and others may become more disposed to the Convention if representations by posts are continued. The process of enactment of domestic legislation, followed in some cases by parliamentary approval of accession, may however cause further delays in those countries referred to above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Reservations and Declarations to Red Cross and other Human Rights Conventions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Brereton

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the instruments ratifying or acceding to Red Cross and other human rights conventions, what reservations or declarations were made by Australia which are still in force.
(2) When was each reservation or declaration last considered.
(3) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying each reservation or declaration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In relation to the Red Cross conventions, Australia made the following declarations:
On ratification of the Geneva Convention relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War (August 12, 1949) on 14 October 1958, Australia made the following declaration:

". . . .and declares that it interprets the term "military installations" in paragraph 2 of Article 68 of the said Convention as meaning installations having an essential military interest for an Occupying Power."

On ratification of the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts (Protocol 1) on 21 December 1991, Australia made the following declarations:
"In depositing its instrument of ratification for Protocol 1, Australia hereby makes declarations of understanding in relation to Articles 5, 44 and 51 to 58 inclusive of the said Protocol.

It is Australia's understanding that in relation to Article 5, with regard to the issue whether, and in what measure, Protecting Powers may have to exercise any functions within the combat zone (such as may be implied by provisions in Parts II and IV of the Protocol), the role of the Protecting Power will be of a like character to that specified in the First and Second Conventions and Part II of the Fourth Convention, which apply mainly to the battlefield and its immediate surroundings.

It is the understanding of Australia that in relation to Article 44, the situation described in the second sentence of paragraph 3 can exist only in occupied territory or in armed conflicts covered by paragraph 4 of Article 1. Australia will interpret the word "deployment" in paragraph 3 (b) of the Article as meaning any movement towards a place from which an attack is to be launched. It will interpret the words "visible to the adversary" in the same paragraph as including visible with the aid of binoculars, or by infra‐red or image intensification devices.

In relation to Articles 51 to 58 inclusive it is the understanding of Australia that military commanders and others responsible for planning, deciding upon, or executing attacks, necessarily have to reach their decisions on the basis of their assessment of the information from all sources, which is available to them at the relevant time.

In relation to paragraph 5(b) of Article 51 and to paragraph 2(a)(iii) of Article 57, it is the understanding of Australia that references to the "military advantage" are intended to mean the advantage anticipated from the military attack considered as a whole and not only from isolated or particular parts of that attack and that the term "military advantage" involves a variety of considerations including the security of attacking forces. It is further the understanding of Australia that the term "concrete and direct military advantage anticipated", used in Articles 51 and 57, means a bona fide expectation that the attack will make a relevant and proportional contribution to the objective of the military attack involved.

It is the understanding of Australia that the first sentence of paragraph 2 of Article 52 is not intended to, nor does it, deal with the question of incidental or collateral damage resulting from an attack directed against a military objective."

In relation to other human rights conventions, I have understood the honourable member's question to mean the major UN human rights treaties to which Australia is a party. The treaties which come within this category and in relation to which Australia has made reservations or declarations upon ratification or accession are as follows:

(a) the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, 7 March 1966. On ratification of the Convention on 30 September 1975, Australia made the following declaration:

"The Government of Australia . . . . . . .declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by article 4(a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, public mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of article 4(a)."
(b)the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, 16 December 1966. On ratification of the Convention on 13 August 1980, Australia made the following reservations and declaration:
Article 10

"In relation to paragraph 2 (a) the principle of segregation is accepted as an objective to be achieved progressively. In relation to paragraph 2(b) and 3 (second sentence) the obligation to segregate is accepted only to the extent that such segregation is considered by the responsible authorities to be beneficial to the juveniles or adults concerned."
Article 14

"Australia makes the reservation that the provision of compensation for miscarriage of justice in the circumstances contemplated in paragraph 6 of article 14 may be by administrative procedures rather than pursuant to specific legal provision."
Article 20

Australia interprets the rights provided for by article 19, 21 and 22 as consistent with article 20; accordingly, the Commonwealth and the constituent States, having legislated with respect to the subject matter of the article in matters of practical concern in the interest of public order (ordre public), the right is reserved not to introduce any further legislative provision on these matters."
Declaration

"Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the constituent States. The implementation of the treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities having regard to their respective constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise."

(c) the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, 18 December 1979. Upon ratification of the Convention on 28 July 1983, Australia made the following declaration and reservations:

"Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the Constituent States. The implementation of the Treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth State and Territory Authorities having regard to their respective constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise."

"The Government of Australia states that maternity leave with pay is provided in respect of most women employed by the Commonwealth Government and the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria. Unpaid maternity leave is provided in respect of all other women employed in the State of New South Wales and elsewhere to women employed under Federal and some State industrial awards. Social security benefits subject to income tests are available to women who are sole parents.

The Government of Australia advises that it is not at present in a position to take the measures required by article 11 (2) (b) to introduce maternity leave with pay or with comparable social benefits throughout Australia.

The Government of Australia advises that it does not accept the application of the Convention in so far as it would require alteration of Defence Force policy which excludes women from combat and combat‐related duties. The Government of Australia is reviewing this policy so as to more closely define "combat" and "combat‐related duties."
(d) the Convention on the Rights of the Child, 20 November 1989. Upon ratification of the Convention on 17 December 1990, Australia made the following reservation:

"Australia accepts the general principles of article 37. In relation to the second sentence of paragraph (c), the obligation to separate children from adults in prison is accepted only to the extent that such imprisonment is considered by the responsible authorities to be feasible and consistent with the obligation that children be able to maintain contact with their families, having regard to the geography and demography of Australia. Australia, therefore ratifies the Convention to the extent that it is unable to comply with the obligation imposed by article 37 (c)."

(2) and (3) The declaration made when Australia ratified the Geneva Convention relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War has not since been considered. No progress has been made on withdrawing or modifying this declaration, and there is no present intention to withdraw or modify it.

The declarations made when Australia ratified Protocol 1 Additional to the Geneva Conventions were last considered prior to ratification on 21 June 1991. No progress has been made in withdrawing or modifying these declarations. The declarations were considered appropriate at the time of ratification, and are still considered appropriate, as the circumstances ruling at that time have not material ly altered. Accordingly there is no present intention to withdraw or modify them.

The declaration made when Australia ratified the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination was last considered in 1995. Withdrawal of the declaration is not possible at this stage. Article 4 (a) of the Convention contemplates the enactment of criminal offences for racial hatred and incitement to racial discrimination. As the Racial Hatred Act 1995 contains only a civil prohibition on such conduct, it does not fulfil Australia's obligations under Article 4 (a) and therefore is not sufficient to allow Australia to withdraw its reservation.

The question of withdrawing or modifying the reservations made when Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is considered every year when Australia's National Action Plan on human rights is updated. Paragraph (c) of the National Action Plan requires Australia to indicate human rights treaty reservations we intend to remove. In relation to the reservation to Articles 10 (2) and (3) of the Covenant, due to Australia's demographic and geographical features it is difficult to achieve the total segregration of accused and convicted prisoners, and children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. Furthermore the Australian Government remains convinced that it is appropriate to allow the responsible authorities discretion to determine whether it is beneficial for a child or juvenile to be imprisoned with adults. However the Government is committed to achieving the goal of separation of accused and convicted prisoners. Given the above, there are no present intentions to withdraw or modify Australia's reservations.

In relation to the reservation to Article 14 of the Covenant, the Australian Government advises that there are administrative procedures available in all Australian jurisdictions to provide compensation for miscarriages of justice in the circumstances envisaged in the Covenant. Accordingly, the reservation to Article 14 is still considered appropriate.

The reservations made when Australia ratified the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women are currently being considered by the Government. It is not known at this stage when a final decision will be taken on withdrawal or modification, and what that decision will be. The declaration made by Australia on ratification of the Convention is still considered appropriate.

The question of withdrawing or modifying the reservation made when Australia ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child is considered every year when Australia's National Action Plan on human rights is updated. In relation to the reservation to Article 37 (1) of the Convention, due to Australia's demographic and geographical features it is difficult to achieve the total segregration of children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. Furthermore the Australian Government remains convinced that it is appropriate to allow the responsible authorities discretion to determine whether it is beneficial for a child or juvenile to be imprisoned with adults. Accordingly, the reservation to article 37 (1) is still considered appropriate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian and New Zealand Membership of the UNESCO and Council of Europe Conventions on Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: To what extent are Australia and New Zealand sharing or contemplating membership of the UNESCO and Council of Europe conventions on education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is a signatory to the following Conventions of the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO):

PARA.TAB: Convention against Discrimination in Education (1960) and a related Protocol instituting a Conciliation and Good Offices Commission for the Settlement of Disputes arising between parties to the Convention (1962)
Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Diplomas and Degrees concerning Higher Education in the States belonging to the Europe Region (1979)
Regional Convention on the Recognition of Studies, Diplomas and Degrees in Higher Education in Asia and the Pacific (1983)

ANSWER.PARA: New Zealand is a party to the 1960 Convention but is not a party to the other three.

UNESCO and the Council of Europe have drafted a joint Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications concerning Higher Education in the European Region. Australia has been invited to become a party to the joint Convention by virtue of being a party to the existing UNESCO Convention on the recognition of qualifications in the European region. The draft has been circulated to the States/Territories for comments as part of nationwide consultations. The draft joint Convention will be discussed at the June 1996 session of the UNESCO Regional Committee, to be held in Rome, and will be tabled for adoption at a UNESCO/Council of Europe conference in 1997.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Paper Mill: Maryvale, Victoria

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 9 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to Amcor's announcement of a $330 million expansion of its paper mill at Maryvale, Victoria.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to anomalies in labelling laws which enable overseas importers to compete unfairly with manufacturers of Australian made copy paper by not clearly identifying the country of origin on wrappers; if so, will he amend regulations made pursuant to the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905 to remove the anomalies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of Amcor's proposed expansion to its Maryvale paper mill. I welcome Amcor's announcement as it represents a strong vote of confidence in the Australian economy.

(2) The current labelling requirement for paper products, made under the Commerce (Imports) Regulations of the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905, is that all imported paper, which is packed for sale on the basis of the number of sheets of paper in the package, must indicate the paper's country of origin. This information is to be marked on the packages in which the goods are packed for sale and, as set out in regulation 8, must be `affixed in a prominent position' in `prominent and legible characters'.

I am not aware of any anomalies in the current regulations which would enable importers to compete unfairly with Amcor, the sole Australian manufacturer of copy paper. However, approximately 12 months ago, in response to industry and union representations, the Australian Customs Service targeted imported paper to examine compliance with the regulations. This investigation found that the bulk of paper imports examined were labelled in a manner required by the Commerce (Imports) Regulations and the country of origin was shown prominently and legibly. The small number of infringements detected were rectified before the Australian Customs Service authorised the delivery of those consignments.
I understand that industry and unions have also raised concerns about false or misleading labelling practices by paper importers with the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission.

I am advised that the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission has responded to these concerns. In particular, I understand that where labelling was found to be potentially false or misleading, the Commission obtained changes to labelling from the importer.
